newsitem.title: USA: Intuit to restructure, lay off 10 percent.
newsitem.headline: Intuit to restructure, lay off 10 percent.

text.p: Intuit Inc, facing slowing sales of its financial software, said Tuesday it plans to consolidate some of its technical support centers around the world and cut about 270 jobs, or 10 percent of its workforce worldwide.
The job cuts will improve operational efficiencies and use its financial resources in new businesses, Intuit said.

Intuit, publisher of the best-selling Quicken personal finance computer program, will close a Rio Rancho, New Mexico, plant where 300 people work. In its place, the company will add 150 jobs to a Tuscon, Arizona, facility.
In Northern California, Intuit will fire 50 people. The company also will centralize its European operations in Munich, cutting about 70 jobs throughout Europe.
Intuit, based in Mountain View, Calif., is the biggest publisher of personal finance and tax preparation software.
Like many other consumer software companies, Intuit has had to slash its product prices in recent months to keep its sales growing.
In late May, the company said it plans to sell its Parsons Technology family software unit so it can concentrate on its core financial software business.
The Parsons' sale and the job cuts will let Intuit concentrate its resources on coming up with financial services through the Internet, Bill Campbell, Intuit president, said.
